Precious metal catalysts have been widely used to catalyze various reactions, particularly three-way catalysts for automobile exhaust purification. Pt, Pd, and Rh, which are dispersed on Ce-based oxides that store and release oxygen, serve as the active center of a catalyst. However, methods to construct multifunctional three-way catalysts to maximize their efficiency and stabilize them are lacking. In this study, Ce-based oxides with a double-stable mode were synthesized to capture and stabilize the precious metals Pt and Rh migrated by Ostwald ripening (OR), and a multicomponent three-way catalyst was accurately synthesized, which showed good catalytic activity and thermal stability. The origin of Ce-based oxides with a dual-stable mode was studied by TEM, XRD, oxygen storage/release capacity and rate test, and XPS. AC-STEM, EXAFS, in situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared, and H2 temperature-programmed reduction studied the OR migration of precious metals and the composition change after aging. Results showed that in the lean/rich oxygen alternating shift atmosphere containing CO, the proportion of OR migration of Pt and Rh precious metals whose initial state is single atoms can reach 100 %. This discovery provides a basic understanding of the sintering mechanism of precious metals, which is of great importance for the development and industrial application of three-way catalysts. Graphical abstract Figure caption: In the lean/rich oxygen alternating shift atmosphere containing CO (automobile exhaust atmosphere), a new method for preparing super stable Pt-Rh alloy three-way catalyst from Pt and Rh single atoms was established with the help of Ostwald ripening migration mechanism. The performance breakthrough was achieved and a new mechanism for improving the thermal stability of highly dispersed metal active centers under real reaction conditions was revealed. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Single-atom catalysis Ostwald ripening migration Double-stable Ce-based oxides Three-way catalysts Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction Supported precious metals, including Pt, Au, Rh, and Pd, have shown broad application potential as catalysts in economically critical industries, such as automotive, petroleum, and environmental industries [1]. Researchers have spent considerable effort to understand the effect of nanoparticle size on catalytic performance and found that the usual deactivation mechanism of supported precious metals is sintering because it caused an undesired reduction in metal surface area [2]. Sintering of supported precious metals involves complex physical and chemical phenomena that have been broadly described by two mechanisms (Fig. S1) [3]. The first mechanism, which involves diffusion, collision, and coalescence of metal nanoparticles, is known as crystallite migration and coalescence (CMC). The second mechanism is known as Ostwald ripening (OR), which involves the movement of a single metal atom in a three-step motion. That is, metal adatoms or metal-ligand complexes were (1) formed and emitted from crystallites [4], (2) diffused in the gas phase or across the support surface [5], and (3) captured by carriers [6]. Given the scarcity of precious metals, researchers tried to inhibit the CMC by using the coating strategy or increasing the interaction between precious metal nanoparticles and carriers [7,8]. However, for Ostwald aging, the suppression of the intrinsic property of precious metals, that is, minimizing excess surface free energy [9], is challenging. In particular, under alternating oxygen-depleted/oxygen-rich atmospheres containing CO, the sintering experimental data of small Pt [10,11], Au [12,13], Rh [14,15], and Pd [16,17] nanoparticles show that OR is the main sintering mechanism. Considering that OR migration has to occur in precious metals, using Ce-based oxides with greater interaction with precious metals is favorable to capture and stabilize precious metals [18]. However, Ce-based oxides must have high enough thermal stability, otherwise they will be sintered together with precious metals (Fig. S2) [19]. In this research, we designed a construction strategy to obtain Ce-based oxides with greater thermal stability (Fig. 1 ). First, Ni-doped CeO2 was synthesized and attached to Al2O3 nanorods. After hydrogen reduction treatment, part of the elemental Ni was precipitated on the CeO2 surface. After oxidation treatment, the elemental Ni becomes NiO and reacts with Al2O3 to form NiAl composite oxides at the contact sites between CeO2 and Al2O3. Based on the DFT calculation, the binding energy of CeO2 on NiAl composite oxides is higher than that on Al2O3 (Fig. 2 ). Next, thin-layer SiO2 was coated. The binding energy of CeO2 on SiO2 is less than that on Al2O3 (Fig. 2). Therefore, the binding energy of CeO2 to contact sites is larger, and the binding energy to noncontact sites is smaller, which endows CeO2 with greater binding energy in the opposite way and in the opposite direction, thereby improving its thermal stability. Therefore, the elemental Ni precipitated by another hydrogen reduction can break the thin layer of SiO2 and replace the precious metals in Na2PtCl6 or Na3RhCl6, thereby achieving the directional anchoring of precious metals on CeO2. Considering the OR migration of precious metals, the migrated precious metals have to fall back to CeO2 rather than Al2O3 because of the binding energy, while the precious metals without OR migration are always on the CeO2. Thus, the precious metals will always be in the highest active site, thereby ensuring the activity of the three-way catalyst. Experimental Simulated auto exhaust gas stream In simulating the composition of automobile exhaust, the following gas supply mode was designed. A main feed stream, containing about 16.3 % CO2, 10 % H2O, 0.3 % CO, 0.1 % H2, 0.6 % O2, 1600 ppm NO, 280 ppm C3H8, 280 ppm C3H6, and 40 ppm SO2 (when used) with balance Ar, was established. A side stream of O2 and a second side stream of CO + H2 were injected alternatively into the main stream to form a periodic, square-wave pattern of exhaust composition. The O2 pulse injection increased O2 concentration to 1.1 % over a 1 s time span. The CO + H2 pulse injection increased CO and H2 to 1.2 % CO and 0.4 % H2 over the next 1 s. The perturbation frequency was 0.5 Hz. The average gas composition was 16.3 % CO2, 10 % H2O, 0.75 % CO, 0.25 % H2, 0.85 % O2, 1600 ppm NO, 280 ppm, C3H8, 280 ppm C3H6, and 40 ppm SO2 (when used) with balance Ar at a space velocity of 50,000 VHSV [20]. The periodic variation of gas composition is illustrated in Fig. S3. Ni-doped CeO2 nanoparticles Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1388 g), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0232 g), and PVP (0.8 g, Basf, K30) were dissolved in 80 ml of anhydrous ethanol. Then, ethanol solution of triethylamine (4 mmol) was added dropwise to the abovementioned solution. After stirring for 10 min, the stock solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 24 h. After being cooled to room temperature, Ni-doped CeO2 nanoparticle suspension was obtained without any other treatment. Al2O3 nanorods The NaOH solution (1 M) was dropped into the Al(NO3)3·9H2O (1 M) solution, resulting in a milky precipitate at pH ∼5. The resultant mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 200 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitates were collected by centrifugation, repeatedly washed with deionized water, and dried. The as-prepared nanorods were calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to obtain Al2O3 nanorods. Al2O3 nanorods loaded with Ni-doped CeO2 (CeNi) A slurry of Ni-doped CeO2 nanoparticles (18.4 ml) and Al2O3 nanorods (100 mg) was sonicated for 30 min. Then, the mixture was evaporated at 60 °C with stirring and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to remove the PVP protectant. The remaining solids after calcination were reduced in 5 % H2/Ar at 400 °C for 2 h to separate Ni from Ni-doped CeO2 and then calcined at 650 °C for 3 h in air to form NiAl composite oxides at the contact sites between CeO2 and Al2O3. CeNi coated with thin-layer SiO2 (CeNiSi) The as-prepared CeNi (50 mg) was redispersed in a mixed solution containing a concentrated ammonia solution (4 ml) and ethanol (80 ml) and ultrasonicated for 30 min. Subsequently, the ethanol solution of tetraethoxysilane (6 mM, 8 ml) was added dropwise to the dispersion under continuous stirring. After stirring for 12 h, the product was collected by centrifuging and washing repeatedly with ethanol and deionized water and dried. Pt catalyst (CeNiSi-Pt) and Rh catalyst (CeNiSi-Rh) The as-prepared CeNiSi was reduced in 5 % H2/Ar at 550 °C for 2 h to separate Ni from Ni-doped CeO2. In the Ar gas atmosphere, elemental Ni replaces Na2PtCl6 (0.03 M) or Na3RhCl6 (0.03 M) at 70 °C, that is, CeNiSi-Pt or CeNiSi-Rh is obtained. Then, the solid was centrifuged and washed three times with deionized water and dried. The ICP test showed that the content of Pt in CeNiSi-Pt and Rh in CeNiSi-Rh accounted for 0.91 % and 0.98 %, respectively [21]. PtRh three-way catalyst (CeNiSi-Pt0.8Rh0.2) 4.3 parts of CeNiSi-Pt and 1 part of CeNiSi-Rh were physically mixed. In the above-mentioned simulated atmosphere, the bimetallic PtRh three-way catalyst (Pt 0.74 wt.%, Rh 0.18 wt.%) can be obtained by OR of precious metals at 500 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C·min−1. The durability test of the catalyst was also completed at 1050 °C for 5 h in a simulated atmosphere [22]. The Na+ content in CeNiSi-Pt0.8Rh0.2 catalyst determined by ICP was 0.13 %, and the Cl− content determined by ion chromatography was 0.03 %. These results show that Na+ and Cl− ions were better removed by three times of washing. Titanium glycol and S-l zeolite were synthesized to verify the OR migration of precious metals [23,24], which are provided in the supporting information. Activity test The experiment on the purification effect of automobile exhaust gas of the CeNiSi-Pt0.8Rh0.2 three-way catalyst was performed in a fixed-bed reactor. The catalyst powder was initially conducted in 40–60 mesh particles and then placed between two stages of quartz cotton. The quartz sand was placed above the quartz cotton as a preheating zone for the reaction gas. At 100 °C-800 °C, each test temperature point should be kept for at least 30 min. Considering that the catalyst has been granulated, the weight of the tested catalyst is slightly different, but it is basically maintained at approximately 60 mg, and the gas flow rate is approximately 50 ml·min−1. Online mass spectrometry and chromatography were used to monitor the gas composition and concentration at the inlet and outlet of the fixed-bed reactor. Characterization Brunauer–Emmett–Teller, XRD, TEM, AC-STEM, XPS, H2-TPR, and SO2-TPD test equipment details can be found in the supporting information, and the measurements were performed following the procedures reported in our previous work [25]. Oxygen storage/evolution properties were investigated through mass spectroscopy (Hiden, HPR-20 EGA). First, the sample was pretreated at 400 °C for 30 min in Ar gas flow and then at 300 °C in Ar gas atmosphere. Afterward, the sample was saturated with 1 % O2 (CO) for 1 min and then purged by Ar gas for 5 min. Finally, the signal was recorded through 1 % CO (O2) gas from the beginning of CO (O2) until the reaction lasted for 70 s. As a kind of oxygen storage and release material, the purpose of CeO2 is to restrain the fluctuation of oxygen, that is, oxygen is stored when there is more oxygen and released when there is less oxygen. Therefore, the better the performance of the oxygen storage material, the smaller the fluctuation of O2 and the smaller the slope. EXAFS measurements were carried out on the sample at beamline 07A1 of Taiwan Light Source (TLS) of National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center (NSRRC). This beamline adopted fixed-exit double crystal Si (111) monochromator to ranging the X-ray energy from 5 - 23 keV. The end-station equipped three ionization chambers and Lytle detector for transmission and fluorescence mode X-ray absorption spectroscopy. The beam size of X-ray on the sample is about 0.5 × 0.25 mm (H × V) with flux higher than 1×1010 photon·s − 1. In situ CO-DRIFTs experiments were performed on a Fourier transform spectrometer (Nicolet IS 50) equipped with a Smart collector and MCT/A detector cooled by liquid N2. First, the sample was pretreated at 300 °C for 30 min in Ar gas flow and then decreased to 30 °C in Ar gas atmosphere. Afterward, the sample was saturated with 1 % CO and then purged by Ar gas for 30 min. Finally, the signal was recorded with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The calculations were carried out using the density functional theory combined with the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof form of generalized gradient approximation functional. The Vienna ab-initio simulation package was also employed. The plane wave energy cutoff was set as 400 eV. The Fermi scheme was used for electron occupancy with an energy smearing of 0.1 eV. The first Brillouin zone was sampled by a 2 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh in the Monkhorst–Pack grid. The energy (converged to 1.0 × 10−6 eV·atom−1) and force (converged to 0.01 eV·Å −1) were set as the convergence criterion for geometry optimization [26–28]. Considering the presence of magnetic atom, spin polarization was considered in all calculations. Results and discussion Double-stable Ce-based oxides Structural model of double-stable Ce-based oxides Increasing the binding energy of the interface between the Ce-based oxide and the carrier can improve its thermal stability [7], which is similar to the stabilizing effect of sand pile on human beings in the graphical figure. In addition, the binding energy of the noncontact surface between the Ce-based oxide and the carrier was weakened. Consequently, Ce-based oxides will continue to migrate until they encounter a more stable site on the carrier. The DFT calculation shown in Fig. 2 indicates that NiAl composite oxides can increase the binding energy of the interface between CeO2 and Al2O3 carriers, whereas SiO2 can reduce the binding energy of noncontact surfaces between CeO2 and Al2O3 carrier [21]. The superposition of the two interactions in the opposite direction, that is, the increase of the interaction in the contact surface and the weakening of the interaction in the noncontact surface, can remarkably improve the thermal stability of Ce-based oxides. These two opposite ways to increase the migration barrier of Ce-based oxides are defined as double-stable mode. Structure of double-stable Ce-based oxides We synthesized three kinds of Ce-based oxides with a particle size of 4–12 nm and dispersed them on Al2O3 nanorods. After aging at 1050 °C for 5 h, the three Ce-based oxides were sintered in different degrees in Fig. 3 . From the view of the change in particle size [29], CeNiSi with a double-stable mode has the best thermal stability. The XRD patterns of Ce-based oxides before and after aging (Figs. 5a and S4) also show that the particle size of CeNiSi is the smallest after aging. Structure of NiAl composite oxides with greater binding energy to Ce-based oxides We first synthesized CeNi complex oxides with a molar ratio of 8: 2. Then part of Ni is precipitated from CeNi complex oxide by hydrogen reduction. After calcination for a certain time, Ni diffuses to the shallow surface of Al2O3 to form NiAl composite oxide. If Ni does not spread into Al2O3, because Ce is fed more, then the element content of Ni must be less than that of Ce. However, as shown in Fig. 4 , the content of Ni in the individual sites of the two line-scans does exceed that of Ce, indicating that Ni is precipitated (also called enrichment). The enriched NiO and Al2O3 react at 650 °C to form NiAl complex oxides. The above inference can be proved at the sites where the content of Ni is higher than that of Ce but less than that of Al. Because Ni does not exist independently in the form of NiO, but reacts with Al2O3 to form NiAl complex oxides, the content of Ni will never exceed that of Al. The formation of NiAl composite oxides between CeO2 and Al2O3 evidently improves the sintering resistance of CeO2. Oxygen storage/evolution properties of double-stable Ce-based oxides The composition of automobile exhaust varies periodically. Therefore, instead of investigating the oxygen storage/release capacity of Ce-based oxides, considerable attention should be paid to the oxygen storage/release rate [30]. Fig. 5 b and c show the differences in oxygen storage/release capacity and rate of the three Ce-based oxides after aging at 1050 °C for 5 h. The area covered under the curve represents the amount of oxygen stored or released, and the slope at the beginning of the curve in the illustration represents the rate. Thanks to the highest Ce3+ ratio shown in Fig. 5e and f [31] and Table S2, the aged CeNiSi has the best oxygen storage/release rate. Given its high thermal stability, CeNiSi has been considered suitable to be used as O2 storage and release material for a three-way catalyst to capture and stabilize precious metals [32]. Ce-based oxides capture precious metals because of OR migration Universality of the OR migration of precious metals Four precious metals, namely, Pt [10,11], Au [12,13], Rh [14,15], and Pd [16,17], are more prone to OR migration in a specific atmosphere, particularly under alternating oxygen-depleted/oxygen-rich atmospheres containing CO. As shown in Fig. 6 , titanium glycol loaded with Pt, Au, Rh, and Pd atoms synthesized by photo-assisted reduction is placed in the upper part of the experimental device, and the S-1 zeolite is placed in the lower part of the experimental device. After treatment under alternating oxygen-depleted/oxygen-rich atmospheres containing CO (simulated auto exhaust gas stream), four precious metals, namely, Pt, Au, Rh, and Pd, can be detected in the S-1 zeolite. Therefore, the four precious metals have undergone OR migration across centimeters. In addition, based on the content of precious metals on the S-1 zeolite after migration, the migration ability of precious metals under the experimental conditions follows the order Pt > Au > Rh > Pd. As shown in Fig. 6d, after various location testing, precious metals were not detected on the outer surface of the S-1 zeolite. Therefore, the OR migration of precious metals is likely to be in the form of monatomic or monoatomic CO complexes [3] because the outer surface of zeolite is small relative to the whole surface area, and most precious metals enter into the pore interior of zeolite. State of precious metals before OR migration Whether the precious metal synthesized by the method proposed in this paper is a single atom, a cluster or a nano-particle can be verified by EXAFS and CO-DRIFT. Fig. 7 a and b show the wavelet transform analysis results of PtO2 and CeNiSi-Pt tested in the same batch. Figs. S5 and S6 shows the Fourier transform analysis results of PtO2, CeNiSi-Pt and Pt foil. As shown in the figures and Table S3, almost all Pt in CeNiSi-Pt is a single atom. The CO-DRIFT results shown in Fig. 7c also show that CeNiSi-Pt has only terminal adsorbed but not bridged adsorbed CO [33], which shows that most Pt exists in the form of a single atom. Fig. S7 shows the CO-DRIFT of CeNiSi-Rh. The figure also shows that most Rh exists in the form of a single atom in three kinds of coordination environment [34]. Double-stable Ce-based oxides and Pt and Rh single atoms are observed, and three-way catalysts can be precisely constructed by OR migration of precious metals. Accurate construction of a multicomponent three-way catalyst Structure of the precisely constructed three-way catalyst Whether it is Pt or Rh catalyst (Figs. S8 and S9), the size of the bright spot measured by AC-STEM (Fig. 8 a and b), that is, the true particle size of precious metals, is smaller than that of the dark spot measured by TEM, that is, the particle size of Ce-based oxides. In addition, the particle-size distribution of Rh is narrower than that of Pt. On the one hand, precious metals exist in the form of a single atom; on the other hand, the reaction atmosphere is the alternating oxygen-depleted/oxygen-rich atmospheres containing CO, both of which are conducive to the OR migration of precious metals. A certain proportion of CeNiSi-Pt and CeNiSi-Rh were physically mixed, and the simulated atmosphere of automobile exhaust induced the OR migration of precious metals to form the PtRh bimetallic three-way catalyst (Fig. 8c). Based on the statistics of the element composition of 10 PtRh alloy particles, the average mass content ratio of Pt and Rh is 8:2, which is consistent with the feed ratio, indicating that most of the precious metals have undergone OR migration. Therefore, the proportion of OR migration of a single atom under the alternating oxygen-depleted/oxygen-rich atmospheres containing CO is close to 100 % [20]. Moreover, PtRh has a core-shell structure, with Pt as the core and Rh as the shell. This finding may be related to the fact that Pt is prone to OR migration(Fig. 6), and it may nucleate first, whereas Rh is more difficult to migrate, and then, it forms a shell. However, after aging at 1050 °C, PtRh alloy and Ce-based oxides are sintered to a certain extent in Fig. 8e, which may explain the loss of activity of the three-way catalyst. Activity of the CeNiSi-Pt0.8Rh0.2 three-way catalyst Pt has a good catalytic conversion effect on CO and non-methane hydrocarbons, and Rh has a good catalytic conversion effect on NO, thereby indicating that CeNiSi-Pt0.8Rh0.2 would be an excellent three-way catalyst. As shown in Fig. 9 , C3H6 and CO in automobile exhaust are relatively easy to be oxidized, and this catalyst also has a good catalytic effect on them. They could be completely converted at 200 °C, and the temperature is only delayed by 20 °C even if the catalyst was aged at 1050 °C. Given the limited loading of Rh, the temperature for the complete catalytic conversion of NO reached 250 °C. When the catalyst was aged at 1050 °C, the temperature for the complete conversion of NO was delayed to 270 °C. C3H8 is difficult to convert in automobile exhaust, and a fresh catalyst can only completely catalyze the conversion of C3H8 at 250 °C, while the temperature of the aged catalyst for the complete conversion of C3H8 was delayed to 310 °C. Causes of the activity loss of three-way catalysts after aging First, as shown in Fig. 3, despite the good thermal stability of CeNiSi, a certain degree of sintering still occurs because of the high aging temperature, which can decrease the stability of precious metals, thereby leading to the sintering growth of precious metals (Fig. 8c and e). Table S4 also shows that the dispersion of precious metals has decreased considerably. The decrease in the number of active sites will lead to the loss of catalytic activity. Second, some changes have taken place in the composition of the PtRh alloy. After aging at 1050 °C, part of Rh will be embedded in Al2O3 nanorods and completely inactivated, which is also proven by the change in element composition (Fig. S10). Based on the element composition of 10 particles, about 20 % of Rh remains in alumina, and this part of Rh corresponds to the reduction peak above 900 °C of H2-TPR (Fig. S11) [35]. The loss of active Rh can greatly affect the elimination of NO. Finally, Fig. S12 shows that the rate of oxygen storage is greatly lost after aging, although the rate of oxygen release from CeNiSi does not change much before and after aging. This result is primarily due to fact that high-temperature aging destroys oxygen vacancies (Ov) of CeNiSi (Fig. S13) [31]. The abovementioned reasons lead to a certain degree of activity loss of the PtRh bimetallic three-way catalyst after aging. As shown in Fig. S14, SO2 interferes with the catalytic activity of the catalyst because of the adsorption of SO2 on precious metals [36]. However, the adsorption of SO2 on the aged precious metals is weak, and SO2 has almost no effect on the catalytic activity of the aged catalysts. Conclusions Our results show that Ce-based oxides with a double-opposite-stable mode have better thermal stability, and the oxygen storage/release performance after aging is better. In addition, Ce-based oxides can capture and stabilize the precious metals migrated by OR. The synthesized Pt and Rh bimetallic three-way catalyst have shown great catalytic potential for automobile exhaust purification at 300 °C. In this study, the characterization of the composition of precious metals before and after aging promoted the understanding of the sintering mechanism of precious metal catalysts. Moreover, by changing the type and proportion of the initial precious metals, more multicomponent and multistructure precious metal catalysts can be synthesized. coredata.dc:description: Precious metal catalysts have been widely used to catalyze various reactions, particularly three-way catalysts for automobile exhaust purification. Pt, Pd, and Rh, which are dispersed on Ce-based oxides that store and release oxygen, serve as the active center of a catalyst. However, methods to construct multifunctional three-way catalysts to maximize their efficiency and stabilize them are lacking. In this study, Ce-based oxides with a double-stable mode were synthesized to capture and stabilize the precious metals Pt and Rh migrated by Ostwald ripening (OR), and a multicomponent three-way catalyst was accurately synthesized, which showed good catalytic activity and thermal stability. The origin of Ce-based oxides with a dual-stable mode was studied by TEM, XRD, oxygen storage/release capacity and rate test, and XPS. AC-STEM, EXAFS, in situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared, and H2 temperature-programmed reduction studied the OR migration of precious metals and the composition change after aging. Results showed that in the lean/rich oxygen alternating shift atmosphere containing CO, the proportion of OR migration of Pt and Rh precious metals whose initial state is single atoms can reach 100 %. This discovery provides a basic understanding of the sintering mechanism of precious metals, which is of great importance for the development and industrial application of three-way catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Double-stable Ce-based oxide: Capturing atomic precious metals via Ostwald ripening for multicomponent three-way catalysts construction
